content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the implementation of your request in Julia:
```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3)
    dt + Hour(bump)
end

# Testing our function
dt = DateTime("2021-01-01T00:00:00")
@assert timezone_bumper(dt) == DateTime("2021-01-01T03:00:00") 
```
In this function, `DateTime` is the input type, which we have checked using the type declaration `::`. The default value of `bump` is set to 3. If no argument is passed for `bump`, it will take a value of 3 as well. This function throws an error when a `Date` object is provided instead of a `DateTime`. This can be enforced using type assertions or type declarations, depending on your requirements.
